tmpls.name: cloze-ol

fields:
A 65 year old female who had a 10 year history of hypertension and a myocardial infarction three years previously, presented to the Emergency Department with sudden onset of weakness in  the left arm and leg.
 
On examination, her pulse was rapid and irregularly irregular. She had a left VII cranial nerve palsy of the upper motor neuron type and left spastic hemiparesis, with an ipsilateral upgoing plantar response

What is the lesion that caused this neurological deficit and what areas are likely to be affected?

1. R sided CVA caused by lenticulostriate artery occlusion or 
2. Haemorrhage (likely Charcot Bouchard aneurysm rupture) affecting internal capsule, basal ganglia and thalamus

A 65 year old female who had a 10 year history of hypertension and a myocardial infarction three years previously, presented to the Emergency Department with sudden onset of weakness in  the left arm and leg. 

On examination, her pulse was rapid and irregularly irregular. She had a left VII cranial nerve palsy of the upper motor neuron type and left spastic hemiparesis, with an ipsilateral upgoing plantar response

What are your differentials?

1. R sided MCA stroke (less likely in this case bc you would see contralateral sensory loss, cortical symptoms and a lower limb sparing)
  2. Brain tumour 
  3. Seizure with post-ictal deficit

How might this pathological process have occurred?

  1. Ischaemic stroke
    - [[oc1::cardiogenic]] embolus (Mural thrombus can be due to AF/MI)
    - [[oc2::carotid]] embolus (from atherosclerosis)

  2. Haemorrhagic stroke
    HTN --> accelerated atherosclerosis --> [[oc3::tunica media thinning]] --> [[oc4::aneurysm]] --> ruptures under HTN --> pressure oedema --> disrupts motor pathways

    - ... embolus (from atherosclerosis)

What is the anatomy and function of internal capsule?

The internal capsule is a [[oc1::white matter]] structure. White matter consists of myelinated and unmyelinated axons and glial cells such as [[oc2::astrocytes]], [[oc3::oligodendrocytes]], and [[oc4::microglial]] cells.

The internal capsule contains both ascending and descending axons --> carries info past the basal ganglia, separating the [[oc6::caudate nucleus]] and the [[oc7::thalamus]] from the [[oc8::putamen]] and the [[oc9::globus pallidus]]. 

The internal capsule is V-shaped when cut in a [[oc10::transverse]] plane and the bend called the genu  containing [[oc11::corticobulbar]] fibres, run between the [[oc12::cortex]] and the [[oc13::brainstem]].

  • The anterior limb is between the [[oc14::head of the caudate nucleus]] and the [[oc15::lenticular nucleus]]
  • The posterior limb is between the [[oc18::thalamus]] and [[oc19::lenticular nucleus]]
    - Contains [[oc20::corticospinal]] fibers, sensory fibers (including the [[oc21::medial lemniscus]] and the [[oc22::anterolateral system]]) from the body and a few [[oc23::corticobulbar]] fibers.

What is the function of the head of caudate nucleus?

The caudate nucleus together with the [[oc1::putamen]] makes up the [[oc2::dorsal striatum]] part of the basal ganglia

  • Motor Functions
- [[oc3::Goal-directed movements]]: Translates idea to move into actual movement, contributes to body & limb posture and speed & accuracy of directed movements
- [[oc4::Spatial mnemonic processing]]: integrates spatial information with motor behaviour formulation
  • Cognitive Functions
    - [[oc5::Memory]], [[oc6::Learning]], [[oc7::Sleep]]

Where are the centres for personality?

  1. Frontal lobes
[[oc1::Higher/executive]] function such as [[oc2::decision making]], [[oc3::consideration of culture, society and religion]].
  1. Limbic system 
Regulates [[oc4::emotions]], [[oc5::behaviour]], [[oc6::motivation]], [[oc7::long-term memory]], and [[oc8::olfaction]].
  1. Hippocampus 
Important for [[oc9::memory formation]]

What functional areas does the MCA supply?

  • Superior division
1. [[oc1::Primary motor cortex]] (precentral gyrus): head shoulders, arms
2. [[oc2::Primary Somatosensory cortex]]  (postcentral gyrus): head, shoulders, arms
3. [[oc3::Association cortex]] (parietal lobe – abstract thinking/language/perception)
4. [[oc4::Broca’s area]] (inferior frontal gyrus of L  frontal lobe) 

  • Inferior division
1. [[oc5::Optic radiation ]]
2. [[oc6::Wernicke’s area]] (Sup. temporal gyrus L temp lobe) 
3. [[oc7::Putamen and GP via lenticulostriate aa]]

What does occlusion of MCA cause?

1. contralateral hemiplegia
  2. hemisensory loss of face & arm
  3. contralateral homonymouse hemianopia (disruption to optic radiation)
  4. dysphasia (dominant)
  5. visuospatial disturbance- cannot dress, gets lost (non dominant)
What types of deficits can unilateral cerebral strokes cause?

1. Motor control
  2. Somatic sensation
  3. Vision
  4. Not hearing, bc auditory information goes to both hemispheres
What effects do you see in occlusion of PCA?

• Supplies occipital lobe
  • Contralateral homonymous hemianopia with macula sparing. If bilateral --> cortical blindness
  • Possible visual agnosia (lack of recognition or understanding of visual objects or constructs)
  • Possible alexia  (disorders of reading)
What can lesions to lenticulostriate aa (of MCA) and Heubner aa (of ACA) cause?

• Pure motor loss: paralyis of face, arm & leg on one side OR
  • Pure sensory loss: mild hemi-numbness OR
  • Mixed sensori-motor
  • Ataxic hemiparesis

What is the blood supply to the visual system?

  1. [[oc1::Central retinal artery]]: retina
  2. [[oc2::Ophthalmic artery]]: optic nerve ([[oc3::prox. 2/3rd]]), muscles, lacrimal duct
  3. [[oc4::ACA]]: optic chiasm and intracranial optic nerve
  4. [[oc5::Anterior choroidal artery]] (branches off the internal carotid artery): Optic tract, lateral geniculate nucleus 
  5. [[oc6::Inferior branches of MCA]]: optic radiation
  6. [[oc7::Calcarine artery branch of PCA + MCA contributions]]: primary visual cortex (posterior pole of the occipital cortex)

Where is the primary visual cortex located?
On either side of the calcarine fissure of the occipital lobe, which is supplied by the posterior cerebral artery
What is the significacne of aneurysm of internal carotic to the visual system?
Internal carotid  is immediately lateral to the chiasm. Aneurysm can cause pressure on the chiasm and cause a partial, nasal hemianopia.

Describe the course and function of ophthalmic artery.

The ophthalmic artery is the first branch of the [[oc1::internal carotid artery]] and goes along the [[oc2::optic nerve]]. It gives off a branch, the [[oc3::central retinal artery]], that penetrates the optic nerve head to spread out over [[oc4::the inner surface of the retina]].

What are the most likely causes of death in the first two weeks following lesion to the internal capsule?

  1. [[oc1::Increased ICP]]
    - [[oc2::Vasogenic and cytotoxic oedema]] --> raised ICP --> tonsillar herniation --> [[oc3::cardiorespiratory failure]]
    - [[oc4::Superimposed haemorrhage]] --> raised ICP --> herniation --> cardiorespiratory failure
  2. Secondary stroke
    - [[oc5::Basilar artery]] --> [[oc6::cardiorespiratory centre hypoperfusion]] --> death
  3. [[oc7::Hospital related causes of death]]
    - PE from immobility and hypercoagulable state 
    - Aspiration pneumonia (impaired cough reflex, hypoventilation)
    - Hospital acquired infection --> Overwhelming sepsis 
          [[oc8::UTI]] (catheter) 
          [[oc9::Staph sepsis]] (cannula)
          [[oc10::Pressure sores]] (immobility)

What are the categories of complications of UC?

Intestinal (acute, chronic)

Extra-intestinal (eyes, skin, joints, haem, hepatobill, bones, dehydration, nails)
What are the acute complications of UC?

• Perforation +/- peritonitis
  • Bleeding (from erosion of an artery, rare, but life threatening)
  • Toxic megacolon +/- rupture
What are the chronic complications of UC?

• Colonic adenocarcinoma (CRC)
  • Perianal abscess
  • Fistula (more likely with Crohn's due to transmural inflammation)
  • Strictures
  • amyloidosis

General
  • [[oc1::nicotine]] abstinence
  • lactose intolerance - [[oc2::lactose-free diet]]
  • appropriate [[oc3::nutrion]] supplementation
  • bile acid diarrhoea - [[oc4::give ion-exchange resins to bind bile acids (eg. cholestyramine) to reduce osmotic diarhhoea (risk of steatorrhoea)]]
  • During acute episodes: [[oc5::avoid dietary fibre, consider parenteral nutrition]]

Pharmacotherapy
  • [[oc6::step up or step down therapy (weak to strong, or strong to weak meds)]]
Surgery
  • [[oc7::
  • if medical therapy fails, or complications (obstruction, fistula, stricture)
  • non-curative, last resort
  • resection of affected bowel
    • ]]
Prevention
  • [[oc8::
  • regular check ups
  • Smoking cessation
  • prophylactic Abx, 5-ASAs, etc
    • ]]

1. Primary Investigations 
[[oc1::ECG (repeated) ]]
  • Possible findings on ECG: 
    • [[oc2::Peaked T waves, ]]
    • [[oc2::ST elevation ]]
    • [[oc2::T wave inversion (24h) ]]
    • [[oc2::q waves (3d), ]]
    • [[oc2::PE]]
Troponin T & I 
  • When is the peak elevation for Troponin, and how fast does it increase? 
    • [[oc3::Peaked 12-24hr (elevated for 1 wk). Increases in 2 hr, CK increases in 6hr ]]
  • What is Troponin 
    • [[oc4::Protein that regulated calcium mediated contraction of cardiac muscle ]]
  1. Secondary Investigations (Bloods) 
[[oc5::FBC – Exacerbating Anaemia or Infection (reduces O2 delivery) ]]
[[oc5::EUC – Potassium levels (risk of arrhythmia), Baseline (to detect progress towards shock) ]]
[[oc5::BGL – Diabetes if >11.1mmol/L (risk factor)]]
[[oc5::HbA1C – >7% (indicative of diabetes) ]]
[[oc5::Lipids – LDL ↑, HDL ↓, Total Chol ↑, TG↑ (risk factor → statin)]]

3. Imaging 
[[oc6::CXR – LVF]]
  • Signs of acute heart failure: 
    • [[oc7::Alveolar oedema]]
    • [[oc7::Kerly B lines]]
    • [[oc7::Effusion]]
  • Signs of chronic heart failure: 
    • [[oc8::Cardiomegaly,]] 
    • [[oc8::Dilated upper vessels]]
Signs of DDx 
[[oc10::TOE - LVF]]
[[oc11::Coronary angiogram – Narrowed segment of a coronary artery (likely LAD) with reduced flow distal to this]]

What is your provisional dx?

28yo sexually active female presents with burning, frequency of urination and discharge

What are your differentials?

  • Infection
- STI – [[oc1::urethritis]] or [[oc2::PID]] (chlamydia, gonorrhea)
- [[oc3::Vaginitis]] (vaginal discharge, itch, burning) 
  • Non-infectious
- [[oc4::Non-infectious urethritis]] (from mechanical irritation) 
- [[oc5::Over-active bladder]] (urgency, frequency, nil UTI) 
- [[oc6::Urothelial carcinoma]] 
- [[oc7::Urolithiasis]]

28yo sexually active female presents with burning, frequency of urination and discharge

What laboratory tests would you like to do?

  • [[oc1::MIDSTREAM Urine dipstick]]: nitrites ++, leukocytes ++  (will also tell you glucose, ketones, protein, etc.)
If +ve for nitrites and leukocytes then treat empirically. If –ve then consider these: 
  • URINE MCS 
- [[oc2::Microscopy and gram staining]] --> leukocytes and or bacteria (93% sensitive and 95% specific when positive)
- [[oc3::Culture & Sensitivity]]: diagnosed at [[oc4::> 10^8 CFU/L]] 
- EUC: check renal function 
- FBC, CRP, Blood cultures: if systemically unwell

What contaminants could you find in an MSU?

• Normal skin or vaginal flora 
  • E. Coli
  • Squamous epithelial cells 
  • Staph saprophyticus

How would you do a MSU?

1. Wash hands & urethra + surrounding skin [[oc1::in normal SALINE]]
2. Begin urination (do not collect [[oc2::first urine passed 20-30mL]]) 
3. Collect urine midway through which is less likely to be contaminated 
4. Tightly cap container 
5. Wash hands 
6. Label container 
7. [[oc3::Take to lab as quickly as possible]] (reduce time allowed for further growth of organisms or alternatively, store at 4 degrees)

protein, blood, albumin, glucose, ketones, leucocytes, nitrites, bilirubin, spec gravity, pH

leucocytes, epithelial cells, red cells, bacteria, casts and crystals
What would you find on urinalysis if there is a UTI?
Which would you most likely see on urine microscopy if there is a UTI?
What organisms would you likely find on a gram stain if there is a UTI?

• gram –ve rods = e. coli, klebsiella, enterobacteria, pseudomonas
  • gram +ve cocci = staphylococcus saphrophyticus, enterococcus
What are the most common organisms for UTI?

1. E. Coli 70-95% (Gram -ve bacillus aerobic and facultative anaerobe)
2. Staph saprophytics 5-20% (gram +ve cocci facultative anaerobe)
3. Proteus mirabilis ~1% (gram -ve facultative anaerobe)
4. Other G-ve: klebsiella, pseudonomas aeruginosa, enterobacter
5. Other G+ve: eneterococcus, staph epidermidis

If you left the urine out for 4 hrs in room temperature, what would happen?
Organisms collected would grow by itself leading to falsely elevated bacterial counts
If you left the urine out for 4 hrs in room temp, what organisms can grow?

• Causative pathogen 
  • Commensals/natural flora (staph epidermidis, staph aureus, strep pyogenes)
If you left the urine out for 4 hrs in room temp, how would this affect the results?

• May give a false +ve if a large increase in a pathogenic organisms level was found 
  • May deem result useless as contaminated if commensals overgrow

How do we test for sensitivity of abx
  • CDS system = [[oc1::Calibration-Dichotomous-Susceptibility]] 
  • Organism is cultured on agar plates containing discs [[oc2::impregnated with different antibiotics]]. 
  • A [[oc3::zone of inhibition]] is seen around those antibiotics the micro-organism is sensitive to 
  • Zone of inhibition = area where no colonies are seen around the antibiotic impregnated disc. [[oc4::≥6mm annulus radius for most antibiotics, ≥2mm if vancomycin]] 
  • The disc itself is 6mm too, so basically a zone with an 18mm diameter must be found to say the micro-organism is susceptible.

Patient presents with a bee sting. Had been stung before but had only a mild response. 
Now presents with tachycardia, tachypnoea, pale, drowsy, angioedema and insp and exp stridor

What is your clinical dx?
Anaphylactic Shock (hypotensive, tachycardic, swollen tongue and urticaria) – a type of ‘distributive’ shock

Patient presents with a bee sting. Had been stung before but had only a mild response. 
Now presents with tachycardia, tachypnoea, pale, drowsy, angioedema and insp and exp stridor

What are your differentials?

Life Threatening
  • Status asthmaticus (atopic, stridor, tachypnoea) 
  • Other forms of shock (Cardiogenic, Obstructive, Hypovolaemic, Distributive) 
Non-life threatening (consider if patient not in shock): 
  • Urticaria/angio-oedema – medications 
  • Asthma 
  • Hyperventilation/panic attack

What would the emergency management for anaphylactic shock be?

Secure Airway: 
  1. Check for [[oc1::foreign body]]
  2. [[oc2::Intubate]] if necessary (airway oedema, trauma, altered respiration)
Check Breathing: 
  1. [[oc3::High flow O2 (>10L/min)]], elevate head of bed 
Provide Circulation support: 
  1. [[oc4::Raise legs above heart]]
  2. [[oc5::2 large bore cannula IV access]]
  3. [[oc6::Bolus]] 
  4. [[oc7::Give adrenaline IM 0.5mg]] (0.5mL of 1:1000) OR if no pulse [[oc8::IV 1mL of 1:10,000]]

What difference in function is there between giving adrenaline vs noradrenaline?

• Adrenaline (more affinity for β receptors --> bronchodilation) vs.
  • Noradrenaline (more affinity for α receptors --> vasoconstriction - use NorAd in septic shock)
How would you manage persistent hypotension in the context of anaphylactic shock?

1. Normal saline (max 50mL/kg)
  2. If cardiogenic cause- IV glucagon bolus 1-2mg
How would you manage upper airway obstruction in the context of anaphylactic shock?
How would you manage persistent wheeze in the context of anaphylactic shock?

1. Bronchodilators (salbutamol 8-12 puffs using spacer 100mcg, or 5mg salbutamol nebuliser)
  2. Oral prednisolone (1mg/kg, max 50mg)

What investigations would you do for anaphylactic shock?

  • Clinical dx
Bedside
  • [[oc1::ECG]] – must do before adrenaline, AMI 
  • [[oc2::Pulse oximetry]] 
Basics
  • [[oc3::ABG]] – mixed respiratory & metabolic acidosis 
  • [[oc4::FBC]] – eosinophilia 
  • [[oc5::EUC]] – renal impairment from shock & K levels in case of arrhythmia
Allergy-Specific
  • [[oc6::Serum tryptase (from mast cells)]] – elevated 1-3 hrs post anaphylaxis 
  • [[oc7::RAST – radioallergosorbent test]] (measures allergen specific IgE in serum): >0.35 IU/L to inciting antigens 
  • [[oc8::Skin test:]] >3mm diameter wheal (good to exclude food allergy) 
  • [[oc9::Challenge test]]
Imaging
  • CXR: exclude CHF, radio-opaque foreign body, pneumonia

Interpret this ABG:
pH 7.24 (lo)
PaO2 52 (lo)
PaCO2 (hi)
Bicarb 18 (lo)
Base excess -6 (lo)
O2 sat (lo)

  • Shows mixed metabolic and respiratory acidosis (low pH) 
  • High PaCO2 = [[oc1::pharyngeal & laryngeal oedema]] --> airway obstruction --> [[oc2::inability to blow off CO2]]. This CO2 + H2O --> [[oc3::H2CO3]] --> acidosis. 
  • PaO2 and O2 Sat ↓= [[oc4::bronchiolar constriction]] impairs O2 exchange & low lung perfusion causes reduced gas exchange 
  • Low O2 = [[oc5::anaerobic metabolism]]--> [[oc6::lactic acidosis]] (anion gap should be [[oc7::↑]]) which uses up [[oc8::HCO3]] --> [[oc9::↓ HCO3 ]]

Provide pathophysiology behind clinical manifestations of anaphylactic shock
  • Inflammation
    - [[oc1::IgE-sensitized mast cells]] from prev. exposure causes degranulation and release of [[oc2::histamine]], [[oc3::tryptase]], [[oc4::PGD2]] and [[oc5::LTD4]] as well as chemotactic factors which all contribute to eventual [[oc6::leukocyte recruitment]] 
  • Bronchoconstriction
    - Tachypnoea and stridor – [[oc7::SMC contraction and laryngeal oedema]]
    - Wheeze and rhonchi – [[oc8::bronchospasm and mucous secretion]]
  • Urticaria and angioedema
    - [[oc9::Vasodilation and increased vascular permeability]]
  • Hypotension with associated poor end organ perfusion (pale, drowsy, incoherent + tachycardia)
    - [[oc10::Vasodilation and extravasation of fluid]]

Explain why patient has reacted with anaphylaxis only now and not previously

Allergic hypersensitivity (type 1) 
  • Mediated by [[oc1::IgE]] antibodies formed in response to a particular allergen/antigen. Bound to [[oc2::mast cells and basophils]]. In sensitised individuals, they respond by [[oc3::synthesising large amounts of IgE to an allergen]].
First exposure to allergen 
  • [[oc4::Dendritic cells]] take up allergen --> present to [[oc5::T cells]] --> differentiate into [[oc6::TH2 cells]] --> TH2 cells stimulate [[oc7::B cells into plasma cells]] --> [[oc8::making IgE]] --> IgE binds to [[oc9::FC component on mast cells]] (arming them) 
(only happens in susceptible people)

Later exposure to allergen (Anaphylaxis) 
  • Binds to IgE on mast cells --> [[oc10::crosslinks IgE]] --> mast cell degranulation 
  • 1° Mediator release (Initial – maximal at 15mins post exposure)
    - [[oc11::Histamine+ LTD4]]  --> [[oc12::↑ Vascular permeability, Vasodilation, Bronchoconstriction, Mucus]] 
    - Adenosine --> [[oc14::bronchoconstriction]] 
    - [[oc15::Tryptase]] --> [[oc16::inflammation and chemotactic factors]] for neutrophils & eosinophils

2° Mediator release (Late-phase – appears at 6hours persists for<72hrs) 
  • [[oc17::Phospholipase A2]] --> AA --> [[oc18::PG (bronchospasm)]] & [[oc19::LT (↑vascular permeability & bronchoconstriction)]] 
  • [[oc20::PAF]] --> platelet aggregation, histamine release & bronchospasm 
  • Mast-cell cytokines [[oc21::(TNF, IL-1, 4 ,5 ,6)]] --> recruit other inflammatory cells

  1. Downregulates [[oc1::inflammatory mediator release]] from mast cells (i.e. histamine, tryptase) --> reduces [[oc2::urticaria, angioedema]]

46F presents for a routine Pap smear. She has been experiencing intermenstrual and post-coital bleeding. 
On speculum exam she has an ulcerated lesion on the cervix. Rest of the vaginal exam appears normal

What is your provisional dx?

46F presents for a routine Pap smear. She has been experiencing intermenstrual and post-coital bleeding. 
On speculum exam she has an ulcerated lesion on the cervix. Rest of the vaginal exam appears normal

What are your differential diagnoses?

Other neoplastic
  • Endometrial/vaginal ca
  • Cervical fibroids (leiomyoma)
  • Cervical endometrial polyp
Pre-malignant
  • CIN (cervical intra-epithelial neoplasia)
  • Cervical adenocarcinoma-in-situ
Infection
  • Cervicitis – infectious (HPV) 
  • PID (chlamydia – obligate intracellular, gonorrhoea – GN cocci)
Benign
  • Nabothian cyst – may be ruptured (cyst on cervix)
  • Endometriosis 
  • Cervical Ectropion – usually in pregnancy or younger women (endocervical protrusion)
What primary investigations would you do for cervical ca?

1. Speculum exam with Papanicolau test: cytobrush with endocervical and endometrial sampling  
  2. Colposcopy: for more definitive diagnosis  
    - Acetic acid staining of dyskaryotic cells --> Cone Biopsy
What laboratory investigations would you perform for cervical ca?

1. FBC: WCC (cervicitis), Hb low if excess bleeding from endometriosis 
  2. EUC & LFT: metastatic disease if suspicious of cervical cancer 
  3. Coagulation studies
  4. [HPV testing]
What imaging would you do for cervical ca?

• Transvaginal Ultrasound: allows good visualisation of cervix, uterus, ovaries and fallopian tubes to evaluate for tumours and cysts 
    - Pelvic U/S can be performed if TVUS did not visualise structures sufficiently 
  • CXR – screen for metastasis
  • Staging imaging – full body CT, PET, bone scan
What is the pathogenesis of cervical ca?

• HPV detected in 85-90% of precancerous lesions and invasive neoplasms
  • High-risk types = 16 [SCC] and 18 [adenoca]
  • Integrate DNA into genome of epithelial cells --> blocks TSGs P53 --> uncontrolled cellular proliferation
What types of pre-cancerous development can you get prior to cervical ca?

• CIN I, II and III (carcinoma in situ)
    - II and III = high grade requiring further colposcopy and diagnostic biospy
  • SIL (Squamous intra-epithelial lesion)

  1. [[oc1::HPV transmission via microabrasions]]
  2. [[oc2::Acute HPV infection (anogenital warts?)]]
  3. [[oc3::Viral persistence + precancerous lesion]]
  4. [[oc4::Basement membrane invasion]]

What prevention measure is there for cervical ca?

• HPV vaccine covering types 6,11,16 and 18
  • Given to women aged between 9-26 as a 3 part course
    - 0,2 and 6 months
What screening measures are in place for cervical ca and consider pros/cons?

• HPV screening for sexually active women 25-74YO every 5 years if low risk & first time 2 years after last normal pap 
Pros
  • Slow progression from CIN to invasive so therefore effective as a form of prevention (may even be 10-20 years)
  • Cervical cancer drop by 70-90% since intro
Cons
  • Cytology does not give clear structure of tissue

42 year old woman who discovered a hard non-tender breast lump 15mm in diameter, cousin had breast cancer

What is your provisional dx?

42 year old woman who discovered a hard non-tender breast lump 15mm in diameter, cousin had breast cancer

What are your differential diagnoses?

Non-malignant
  1. Cystic/fibrocystic change (pain during luteal phase)
  2. Fat necrosis (hx of trauma)
  3. Breast Abscess or mastitis
  4. Lipoma
Malignant – non-invasive
  1. DCIS
  2. Paget’s disease (extension of DCIS into lactiferous ducts and areola)
  3. LCIS
Malignant  - Invasive
  1. Invasive ductal cell carcinoma
  2. Invasive lobular cell carcinoma
  3. Medullary carcinoma
  4. Colloid/mucoid carcinoma
What further hx would arouse suspicion of breast ca?

1. Size change: gradual increase = cancer, fluctuating = fibrocystic change 
  2. Axillary Lymphadenopathy 
  3. Systemic features (weight loss, night sweats, setc.) and signs of metastases (lung, bone, liver)
  4. Prev hx 
  5. Family hx – 1°, genetic (BRCA ½)
What exam findings would arouse further suspicion of breast ca?

• Systemic signs --> cachexia
  • Mets screen- peripheries (lymphadenopathy), bony tenderness, hepatomegaly, resp (cough/pneumonia)
Breast 
  1. Overlying skin changes (erythema, peau d’orange – skin dimpling)
  2. Nipple inversion, discharge and signs of pargets
  3. Palpation (fixed/mobile, hardness, tenderness, irregularity)
  4. Hard, irregular, non-tender = malignant
  5. Well-circumscribed, mobile, rubbery = fibroadenoma
Significance of family hx and breast ca?

1. A 1o Relative with unilateral Breast Ca = 2.0x RR increase 
  2. A 1o Relative with bilateral Breast Ca = 5.0x RR increase 
  3. Family hx of ovarian ca = 5.0x RR increase

List other risk factors for breast ca
  • Related pathology
    - [[oc1::LCIS or DCIS]] = 7-12x RR 
    Past history = 5.0x RR 
  • Family hx of [[oc2::ovarian cancer]] = 5.0x RR 
  • Age [[oc3::>50]] = 4.0x RR 
  • [[oc4::BRCA1/2 (AD - tumour suppressor genes) +ve]] = 4.0x RR 
  • [[oc5::High oestrogen exposure]] 
  • [[oc6::Smoking]] = 1.5x RR

What are some causes of increased estrogen exposure?

• Nulliparous = 3.0x RR 
  • First live birth >35 = 1.9x RR 
  • Overweight/obese = 1.5x RR 
  • Late menopause = 1.5x RR 
  • OCP = 1.2x RR increase

Dx for breast ca requires Triple Assessment
  1. Clinical examination – Lump and nodes 
  2. Imaging (U/S <35, mammography+ US >35) 
  3. Biopsy for Cytology/histology
When do you use U/S vs mammogram?

• <35y = US only, mammogram useless as breast tissue too dense 
  • >50y = mammogram +/- US as breast is less dense (more adipose, less ligaments & ducts by %)

Does fibrocystic change predispose to carcinoma?

Benign breast lesions can be classified histologically into three categories: 
  1. Non-proliferative e.g. [[oc1::breast micro/macro cyst]], [[oc2::stromal fibrosis]]
    - Exaggerated response of normal breast changes that occurs in menstrual  cycle
    - [[oc3::Confers negligible increased risk]] of carcinoma 
  2. Proliferative e.g. [[oc4::Epithelial hyperplasia]], [[oc5::sclerosing adenosis]] (glandular aggregation and fibrous overgrowth)
    - Small increased risk of developing breast cancer = [[oc6::1.5-2.5x]]
  3. Atypical lobular hyperplasia = x5 risk

Macroscopic

Microscopic

A 65 year old man presented to the Emergency Department with a six-hour history of interscapular pain, urinary retention and mild bilateral leg weakness. On further questioning, he revealed that he had felt unwell for six weeks and had lost 3 kg in the past month. 

On examination he had a distended bladder, signs of motor dysfunction in both legs, decreased sensation to the level of his rib cage and reduction in vibration sense below his iliac crest. 

What is your provisional dx?

• Spinal Metastases --> spinal cord compression
  • Note: Cancers metastasising to bone = lung, prostate, breast, colon, myeloma, kidney

A 65 year old man presented to the Emergency Department with a six-hour history of interscapular pain, urinary retention and mild bilateral leg weakness. On further questioning, he revealed that he had felt unwell for six weeks and had lost 3 kg in the past month. 

On examination he had a distended bladder, signs of motor dysfunction in both legs, decreased sensation to the level of his rib cage and reduction in vibration sense below his iliac crest. 

What are your differential diagnoses?

1. Vertebral # (OP --> crush # --> retro-pulsion of fragment impinges spinal cord) 
  2. Vertebral Disk Herniation 
  3. Osteomyelitis/Abscess (UTI or other infection source spreading to spine ) 
Pott’s Disease (TB --> vertebral osteomyelitis) 
Paget’s Disease 
Spondylolisthesis (zygapophyseal joint dislocation – would likely need to be bilateral) 
Multiple myeloma (myeloma --> lytic lesion --> pathological fracture)

A 65 year old man presented to the Emergency Department with a six-hour history of interscapular pain, urinary retention and mild bilateral leg weakness. On further questioning, he revealed that he had felt unwell for six weeks and had lost 3 kg in the past month. 

On examination he had a distended bladder, signs of motor dysfunction in both legs, decreased sensation to the level of his rib cage and reduction in vibration sense below his iliac crest. 

What investigations are appropriate?

Bedside 
Urinalysis

Bloods
FBC: 
  • normochromic, normocytic anaemia and thrombocytopenia (bone marrow involvement)
  • Raised WCC (osteomyelitis)
  • CMP (↑Ca2+, paraneoplastic effect) 
  • ALP (↑in bony mets) 
  • EUC (↑ in urinary retention 2o to prostate cancer causing obstruction) 
  • LFT (mets) 
  • PSA & DRE (↑ suggests prostate cancer, >20ng/mL --> bone scan) 
Imaging 
  • MRI/CT spine (osteoblastic lesions in prostate ca) 
  • CXR (TB, malignancy) 
  • Transrectal U/S & biopsy
  • Bone scan (mets-later)

Discuss public health perspectives of PSA screening

Pros
  1. [[oc1::Detect prostate cancer early (usually is asymptomatic) ]]
  2. [[oc2::Men diagnosed with early PCa live longer c.f. more advanced ca ]]
  3. [[oc3::PCa which has spread outside of prostate is generally incurable]]

Describe the prostate

A [[oc1::glandular]] organ with a [[oc2::fibromuscular]] capsule shaped like an [[oc3::inverted pyramid]] which surrounds the [[oc4::neck of the urinary bladder]]. It contains the [[oc5::two ejaculatory ducts]] which both join with the [[oc6::proximal urethra]] to form the [[oc7::prostatic urethra]].

Signs and symptoms of BPH?

(mostly from obstruction)
Urgency
Below the prostate is the [[oc1::urethral sphincter]], and above it is the [[oc2::vesical sphincter]]. When the [[oc3::vesical sphincter]] is encroached upon, leads to leakage of urine into the [[oc4::prostatic urethra]] and an intense desire to micturate

Hesitancy
Enlarged [[oc5::median lobe]] can also compress the [[oc6::urethral orifice]] in the bladder and act like a [[oc7::flap valve]] every time the pressure (to pee) rises, leading to [[oc8::difficulty starting a stream]]

Poor stream
Once stream starts, poor stream  because the [[oc9::prostatic urethra]] is elongated, compressed and distorted  by the [[oc10::expanding medial and lateral lobes]]

How does PCa spread haematogenously?

[[oc1::Prostatic venous plexus]] ([[oc2::Batson's plexus]]) is a venous plexus that is [[oc3::THIN walled]] and [[oc4::VALVELESS]] and communicates with the [[oc5::vesical veins]] and, importantly, the [[oc6::spinal venous plexus]]. 

It is supposed to drain into the [[oc7::internal iliacs]] ultimately. However, because it is valveless, during  [[oc8::coughing or straining]], there can be [[oc9::RETROGRADE flow]] from the [[oc10::Batson's plexus]] to the [[oc11::spinal venous plexus]], and cancer cells can float up this  [[oc12::valveless venous system]] all the way up to the skull. 

This explains the  frequent occurrence of skeletal mets in the [[oc13::lower veterbral column]] and  [[oc14::pelvic bones]] in prostate cancer

No cough means [[oc15::IVC]] drains to [[oc16::lung]] (lung mets, liver mets)

What is the Gleason Score?

  • Grading system used to determine the [[oc1::aggressiveness]] of PCa 
  • Ranges from [[oc2::1-5]] and describes how much the cancer from a biopsy looks like healthy ([[oc3::lower score]])/abnormal ([[oc4::higher score]]) tissue
  • Since prostate tumors are often made up of cancerous cells that have different [[oc5::grades]], two grades are assigned for each patient.  
  • A primary grade is given to describe the cells that make up the [[oc6::largest area of the tumor]] and a secondary grade is given to describe the cells of [[oc7::the next largest area]].  
  • For instance, if the Gleason Score is written as 3+4=7, it means most of the tumor is grade 3 and the next largest section of the tumor is grade 4, together they make up the total Gleason Score.

What is the Gleason Score?

  • Grading system used to determine the {{c21::aggressiveness}} of PCa 
  • Ranges from {{c21::1-5}} and describes how much the cancer from a biopsy looks like healthy ({{c21::lower score}})/abnormal ({{c21::higher score}}) tissue

• If Gleason score 2-5 (out of 10) = watch and wait

  • If gleason score greater --> radical prostactectomy

What are the risk factors for ischaemic stroke? (CVD factors + AS)

Non-modifiable
  • Age 
  • Feale gender 
  • FH
  • Past TIA or MI
  • Thrombophilia (Anti-thrombin 3 deficiency) 
  • Pregnancy, cancer and other hypercoagulable states 

Modifiable 
  • AF 
  • Smoking 
  • DM 
  • CKD
  • Obesity 
  • Hypercholesterolaemia
What are the risk factors for haemorrhagic stroke? (HTN + AS)

Non-modifiable 
  • Age
  • Male gender
  • FH
  • CT disease e.g. Ehler Danlos, vasculitis 

Modifiable
  • HTN 
  • Anticoagulant Rx
+ risk factors for ischaemic stroke, as it can contribute to AS
What are some physical examination findings you may find with people with cardiovascular risk factors?

• General inspection: obesity, male, age, marfan’s
  • Hands: nicotine staining, clubbing (cyanotic heart disease), xanthomma
  • Pulse: irregularly irregular
  • BP: hypertensive
  • Face: xanthelesma, diabetic retinopathy
  • Chest: sternotomy scar, lateral displaced apex, thrills, murmurs
  • Carotids: bruits 
  • Abdomen: AAA 
  • Legs: skin changes, ulcers, pulses absent, PVD
